text:

Gujarat High Court

Raju Krupagiri Rajput vs State Of Gujarat on 13 January, 2025

 NEUTRAL CITATION

 R/CR.MA/25055/2024 ORDER DATED: 13/01/2025

 undefined

 IN THE HIGH COURT OF GUJARAT AT AHMEDABAD
 R/CRIMINAL MISC. APPLICATION NO. 25055 of 2024
 (FOR SUCCESSIVE REGULAR BAIL - AFTER CHARGESHEET)

 =======================================================
 RAJU KRUPAGIRI RAJPUT
 Versus
 STATE OF GUJARAT
 =======================================================
 Appearance:
 S D MANSURI(7509) for the Applicant(s) No. 1
 MR SOAHAM JOSHI APP for the Respondent(s) No. 1
 =======================================================

 CORAM:HONOURABLE MR. JUSTICE DIVYESH A. JOSHI

 Date : 13/01/2025

 ORAL ORDER

 1. The present application, which is a successive
 bail application after the rejection of earlier
 bail application being Criminal Misc. Application
 No.18701/2023 vide order dated 04.12.2023, is
 filed under 
Section 439
 of the Code of Criminal
 Procedure, 1973, for regular bail in connection
 with the FIR being C.R. No.III-8/2022 registered
 with the ATS Police Station, Ahmedabad for the
 offence punishable under 
Sections 8(c)
, 
21(c)
 and
 
29
 of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic
 Substance Act, 1985.

 2. Heard learned advocate, Mr. S.D. Mansuri for the
 applicant and learned APP Mr. Soaham Joshi for the
 respondent - State of Gujarat.

 3. Learned advocate for the applicant submitted that
 the so-called incident has occurred in the evening

 Page 1 of 7

Uploaded by PATIL GAUTAMBHAI GOPALBHAI(HC00190) on Mon Jan 13 2025 Downloaded on : Mon Jan 13 21:50:01 IST 2025

 NEUTRAL CITATION

 R/CR.MA/25055/2024 ORDER DATED: 13/01/2025

 undefined

 of 30.11.2022, for which, FIR has been lodged on
 the very same day i.e. on 30.11.2022 and in
 connection with the same, the applicant has been
 arrested on 11.01.2023 and since then, he is in
 judicial custody. Learned advocate submitted that
 the applicant is not named in the FIR and only on
 the basis of the statement of the co-accused, the
 applicant is arraigned as accused. Learned
 advocate submitted that the applicant was not
 found in conscious possession of the prohibited
 contraband articles and there is no recovery or
 discovery at the instance of the present applicant

 - accused.

 4. Learned advocate, at this stage, submitted that
 this is a successive bail application preferred by
 the application after the rejection of earlier
 bail application being Criminal Misc. Application
 No.18701/2023 vide order dated 04.12.2023, however
 while rejecting said application, the aspect of
 non-compliance of the mandatory provision of
 
Section 52A
 of the NDPS has not been considered
 and wrongly rejected the said application because
 the communication in that regard, which had been
 undertaken by the IO for complying with the said
 provision, is not part and parcel of the
 chargesheet papers. It is, therefore, submitted
 that only on that count, the bail application of
 the applicant may be considered and the applicant
 may be granted bail. Learned advocate further
 submitted that the applicant is in jail since

 Page 2 of 7

Uploaded by PATIL GAUTAMBHAI GOPALBHAI(HC00190) on Mon Jan 13 2025 Downloaded on : Mon Jan 13 21:50:01 IST 2025

 NEUTRAL CITATION

 R/CR.MA/25055/2024 ORDER DATED: 13/01/2025

 undefined

 11.01.2023 and thus, more than 12 months are over
 and, therefore, the applicant may not be kept
 behind the bar for indefinite period. He further
 submitted that even in recent past, the Hon'ble
 Supreme Court has also issued guidelines in case
 of delay in trial and the fact that "bail is a
 rule" and "jail is an exception". It is,
 therefore, urged that the present application may
 be allowed.

 5. On the other hand, learned APP, Mr. Joshi for the
 respondent-State has opposed grant of regular bail
 looking to the nature and gravity of the offence.
 He submitted that in fact, at the time of hearing
 of earlier bail application, all the aspects
 raised by learned advocate for the applicant have
 been considered and as stated above, this is a
 successive bail application preferred by the
 applicant but there is no changed circumstances
 for filing such application. He further submitted
 that in fact, the aspect of non-compliance of the
 provision of 
Section 52A
 of the NDPS has been
 considered by the Coordinate Bench of this Court
 while passing an order dated 21.08.2024 in
 Criminal Misc. Application No.19761/2023 in case
 of co-accused and the Coordinate Bench of this
 Court has rejected the said application
 considering the said fact, therefore, reliance
 placed by learned advocate for the applicant on
 that aspect cannot be considered at this stage.

 6. Learned APP submitted that the present application

 Page 3 of 7

Uploaded by PATIL GAUTAMBHAI GOPALBHAI(HC00190) on Mon Jan 13 2025 Downloaded on : Mon Jan 13 21:50:01 IST 2025

 NEUTRAL CITATION

 R/CR.MA/25055/2024 ORDER DATED: 13/01/2025

 undefined

 is a successive bail application after the
 rejection of earlier bail application, however,
 the present application is preferred without
 disclosing any changed circumstance except abvoe
 and, hence, this application can be said to be
 'review application' and power of review
 application is very limited and when there is
 technical and/or arithmetical error, review
 application can be preferred, which can be
 entertained but in the present case, the applicant
 has failed to show any changed circumstance and
 the reasons, which are mentioned in the memo of
 application, were at all available at the earlier
 point of time when earlier bail application was
 rejected.

 7. I have heard the learned advocates appearing on
 behalf of the respective parties and perused the
 papers of the investigation and considered the
 allegations levelled against the applicant and the
 role played by the applicant. I have also
 considered the reasoning given by the concerned
 court while rejecting the bail application and the
 affidavit filed by the IO opposing the said
 application.

 8. It is the settled position of the law that, at
 this juncture detailed discussion of evidence and
 canvassing of the allegations contained in FIR as
 well as affidavit of the concerned Investigating
 Officer or the merits of the case as well, is not
 necessary and should be avoided.

 Page 4 of 7

Uploaded by PATIL GAUTAMBHAI GOPALBHAI(HC00190) on Mon Jan 13 2025 Downloaded on : Mon Jan 13 21:50:01 IST 2025

 NEUTRAL CITATION

 R/CR.MA/25055/2024 ORDER DATED: 13/01/2025

 undefined

 
9. It is a well settled principle of law that when
 the successive application comes before the Court,
 the Court would be very conscious while
 considering the same. It is also a settled
 position of law that successive bail applications
 are permissible under the change circumstances and
 the change circumstances must be substantial one
 which has direct impact on the earlier decision
 and not merely a cosmetic changes which are of
 little or no consequences. As held by the Apex
 Court in 
State of Maharashtra Vs. Captain
 Buddhikota Subha Rao
, reported in AIR 1989 SC
 2292, that successive bail application can be
 entertained by the Court when substantial change
 is established by the accused, which would entitle
 him for getting bail in successive bail
 application. The Court should not pass the order
 of releasing him on bail in successive bail
 application merely establishing some cosmetic
 change between time gap of two applications. There
 should be drastic change during the period between
 two applications, which would entitle the accused
 for bail.
 The Apex Court in the case of
 Kalyanchandra Sarkar Vs. Rajesh Ranjan, reported
 in (2005) 2 SCC 42 while dealing with the issue of
 successive bail application has observed that
 without change in the circumstances, the
 subsequent bail application would be deemed to be
 seeking a review of the earlier rejection order
 which is not permissible under the criminal law.

 Page 5 of 7

Uploaded by PATIL GAUTAMBHAI GOPALBHAI(HC00190) on Mon Jan 13 2025 Downloaded on : Mon Jan 13 21:50:01 IST 2025

 NEUTRAL CITATION

 R/CR.MA/25055/2024 ORDER DATED: 13/01/2025

 undefined

 The Apex Court has further observed that while
 entertaining such undefined consequent bail
 application, the Court has a duty to consider the
 reasons and grounds on which the earlier bail
 application was rejected and what are the fresh
 grounds which persuade it warranting the
 evaluation and consideration of the bail
 application afresh and to take a view different
 from one taken in the earlier application.

 10. It is found out from the arguments canvassed by
 learned advocate for the applicant that main
 argument of learned advocate for the applicant is
 with regard to non-fulfillment of the required
 procedure as envisaged under 
Section 52A
 of the
 NDPS Act and on the strength of the said argument,
 bail is sought for. It is, however, required to be
 noted that as can be found from the submissions
 canvassed by learned APP that in case of co-
 accused, who had filed Criminal Misc. Application
 No.19761/2023, the Coordinate Bench of this Court,
 after considering the submissions and considering
 the said aspect, has rejected the said application
 by detailed order. It is submitted that it is
 specifically observed in the said order that the
 procedure under 
Section 52A
 of the NDPS has been
 carried out by the Investigating Agency belatedly
 but the said aspect is a matter or proof and would
 required consideration at the time of trial. Thus
 the said view adopted by the Coordinate Bench of
 this Court can be said to be just, legal and

 Page 6 of 7

Uploaded by PATIL GAUTAMBHAI GOPALBHAI(HC00190) on Mon Jan 13 2025 Downloaded on : Mon Jan 13 21:50:01 IST 2025

 NEUTRAL CITATION

 R/CR.MA/25055/2024 ORDER DATED: 13/01/2025

 undefined

 proper, which in my considered opinion, applies in
 the facts of the present case. Over and above,
 learned advocate has failed to point out any
 changed circumstances. Therefore in absence of any
 changed circumstances, once again present
 application is preferred agitating same grounds,
 which in the opinion of this Court, is not
 available to the applicant in a successive bail
 application.

 11. Over and above that, strong apprehension has been
 shown by prosecution that if the applicant is
 released on bail then, there is possibility of
 tampering with the evidence and fleeing away from
 the trial. Therefore considering the nature of
 offence, role attributed to the applicant and
 played by him, I am of the opinion that the
 present application deserves to be rejected.

 12. In view of the facts and circumstances of the
 present case, this Court is of the view that after
 the rejection of earlier regular bail application,
 there is no change in the circumstances.
 Accordingly, the present application is rejected.

 13. Needless to say that any expression of opinion
 given in this order does not mean an expression of
 opinion on the merits of the case and the trial
 Court will not be influenced by any observations
 made therein.

 (DIVYESH A. JOSHI, J.)
 Gautam

 Page 7 of 7

Uploaded by PATIL GAUTAMBHAI GOPALBHAI(HC00190) on Mon Jan 13 2025 Downloaded on : Mon Jan 13 21:50:01 IST 2025

CORAM:HONOURABLE MR. JUSTICE DIVYESH A. JOSHI

1. The present application, which is a successive

11.01.2023 and thus, more than 12 months are over

 He submitted that in fact, at the time of hearing

6. Learned APP submitted that the present application

is a successive bail application after the

9. It is a well settled principle of law that when
 the successive application comes before the Court,
 the Court would be very conscious while
 considering the same. It is also a settled
 position of law that successive bail applications
 are permissible under the change circumstances and
 the change circumstances must be substantial one
 which has direct impact on the earlier decision
 and not merely a cosmetic changes which are of
 little or no consequences. As held by the Apex

State of Maharashtra Vs. Captain
 Buddhikota Subha Rao
, reported in AIR 1989 SC
 2292, that successive bail application can be

The Apex Court has further observed that while

Section 52A

Section 52A

 the said view adopted by the Coordinate Bench of
 this Court can be said to be just, legal and

proper, which in my considered opinion, applies in

 which in the opinion of this Court, is not

 Accordingly, the present application is rejected.

13. Needless to say that any expression of opinion

citations.case_name:
Gujarat High Court

Raju Krupagiri Rajput v. State Of Gujarat on
citations.raw:
Gujarat High Court

Raju Krupagiri Rajput vs State Of Gujarat on

suggested_precedents.full_citation: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar, (2014) 8 SCC 273
suggested_precedents.legal_principle: Mandatory arrest not required for offences punishable less than 7 years
